bibl.title: Letter from Margaret Deland to James E. Peabody, June 8, 1927

div1.p: Deland thanks Peabody for his work for Kissinger. She offers to lobby Congress and sends a check to Ida Kissinger.

div1.head: Letter from Margaret Deland to James E. Peabody, June 8, 1927
div1.p:
Thank you very much for your letter of June 4th. I am greatly relieved
and reassured by what you tell me you have accomplished. When I read
that dreadful little newspaper clipping, it seemed to me that a world
where the Imponderables--love, courage, endurance and sacrifice--could
be forgotten or at least ignored, was not worth living in! This is prob-
ably because I am getting old and stupid, and realize my own powerless-
ness to help along; but when I read what you have accomplished in the way
of bringing these Imponderables home to us, I do lift up my heart! How
perfectly splendid it is to have Dr. Fosdick's voice summoning people to
get busy about Kissinger and the others! Now as you say, the thing is
to arouse Congress. But when you say that, I feel as if you were under-
taking to clean the Augean stables. But you will do it!

I am so glad to know there is any chance of meeting you and Mrs. Pea-
body this summer. My friend, Miss Annable, and I are here in my little
house by the river, with our big sheep dog, Roger; and if, when you reach
Pine Point, you will come and have lunch with us some day, you will give
us great pleasure. I wondered, as I read your letter, whether you would
be willing to let me ask some people to meet you after luncheon--so that
you could tell us whether we could be of any use about the “Stables”?
I am pretty sure more money will come in; but of course what you want
now, is to put firecrackers under the chair of every Congressman in this
forgetful democracy of ours. How can we help do it?

Will you give this little check (it is so little I am ashamed to send
it to you!) to Mrs. Kissinger, from me, and say I hope she can use it for
her garden?--That is, if her garden is like mine in its demand for fer-
tilizers, and bone meal, and all the rest of the things a garden clamors
for!

I am so glad that you liked Dr. Lavendar. I wonder what he would
think of the world as it is now. As for Willy King, do you suppose he
really could have believed that mosquito netting would make it possible
to build the Panama Canal?

I am venturing to keep the letters you sent me for a few days, because
I want to read them to one or two people up here, with a view to inter-
esting them in firecrackers.
div1.closer:
Faithfully yours, Margaret Deland. (Author of “The Rising Tide”, “Around Old Chester”, “The Hands of Esau,2”
“)ld Chester Tales,” “An Encore,” “Dr. Lavendar's People,” “Good for-
the Soul,” “The Awakening of Helena Richie,” “Partners,” “R. J's Mother,”
“The Common Way,” “The Iron Woman,” “The Voice,” “The Way to Peace,”
“Where the Laborers are Few,” “John Ward, Preacher,” and others.
